page.title: 08Darenth Woods in April
page.content: Entering the sessile oak and birch woodland lying on the lighter soils of the plateau gravel, we were greeted by the songs of the blackcap and willow warbler. Under the fairly open canopy the ground cover of bramble was quite dense but we noticed an extensive patch of large wood rush and the leaves of numerous lily of the valley. Moving down the slope, the oak is partially replaced by sweet chestnut. This casts a denser shade and the bramble had decreased. Further down in the transitional zone marked by coppiced hornbeam, wood anemones were abundant. Large patches of dog's mercury were common and among them leaves of wood sorrel, not yet in flower. Birch polypore fungus had killed several trees. A pair of green woodpeckers could be heard drilling in the rotten wood to find insects.
